Estimates the imbalance ablation based on the total glacier discharge

Source: R/glacierImbalAbl.R
glacierImbalAbl.Rd

The regression is derived from the data set by Miles et al., 2021 (glacier imbalance ablation imbalAbl) and Hugonnet et al, 2021 (specific glacier melt dmdtda). In our modelling framework the glacier discharge is a positive number while in Miles glacier balance model it is a negative number. Note that imbalance ablation computed here is consistent with Miles glacier balance model: negative imbalance ablation indicates glacier loss and positive glacier imbalance ablation indicates glacier gain. Contrary to the literature, where glacier growth can be observed, this model does not allow for glacier growth.

glacierImbalAbl(Melt_mma)

Source

Miles et al., 2021, DOI: <https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-021-23073-4> and Hugonnet et al., 2021, DOI: <https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-021-03436-z>

Arguments

Melt_mma

Specific glacier melt in mm/a. A positive number

Value

Imbalance ablation component of total ablation in m3/a. Negative for glacier melt and positive for glacier gain.

Details

The relative error of the function is estimated to be 0.73 [vignette glaciers 02]glaciers-o2-DDMWB.html on a demonstration how to use that information.

See also

Other glacier functions: glacierArea_Erasov(), glacierArea_RGIF(), glacierBalanceP(), glacierBalance(), glacierDischargeRMSE(), glacierDischarge_HM(), glacierMelt_TI(), glacierRMSE(), glacierTotalAblation_HM(), glacierVolume_Erasov(), glacierVolume_RGIF()

Examples

  imbalAbl_m3a <- glacierImbalAbl(c(1,2,3,4,5)*10^3)
